nodes.label: David Foster Wallace
nodes.description: American author known for his encyclopedic novel 'Infinite Jest'.

nodes.label: Infinite Jest
nodes.description: A massive and complex novel exploring themes of addiction, entertainment, and despair in a near-future America.

nodes.label: Jorge Luis Borges
nodes.description: Argentine master of the short story, who played with concepts of infinity, reality, and identity.

nodes.label: Labyrinths
nodes.description: A collection of stories and essays that epitomize his philosophical and fantastical style.

nodes.label: Italo Calvino
nodes.description: Italian writer and a member of the Oulipo group, known for his playful and imaginative narratives.

nodes.label: If on a winter's night a traveler
nodes.description: A postmodern novel about the reader trying to read a book of the same name.

nodes.label: Thomas Pynchon
nodes.description: A reclusive American novelist known for his dense, complex, and maximalist works.

nodes.label: Gravity's Rainbow
nodes.description: A sprawling novel set in Europe at the end of WWII, revolving around the German V-2 rocket.

nodes.label: Virginia Woolf
nodes.description: An English writer and a pioneer of the stream of consciousness narrative technique.

nodes.label: To the Lighthouse
nodes.description: A novel that captures the inner lives and thoughts of its characters during visits to the Isle of Skye.

nodes.label: James Joyce
nodes.description: An Irish novelist, a central figure in the modernist avant-garde.

nodes.label: Ulysses
nodes.description: A landmark work of modernism that parallels Homer's Odyssey, set in Dublin on a single day.

nodes.label: Mark Z. Danielewski
nodes.description: American author known for his ergodic novel 'House of Leaves'.

nodes.label: House of Leaves
nodes.description: A novel with an unconventional page layout and story structure, requiring active participation from the reader.

nodes.label: Kurt Vonnegut
nodes.description: American writer known for his satirical and darkly humorous novels.

nodes.label: Slaughterhouse-Five
nodes.description: An anti-war novel about the bombing of Dresden, told in a non-linear, science-fictional style.

nodes.label: Georges Perec
nodes.description: A French novelist and member of the Oulipo group, known for his formal constraints.

nodes.label: Life: A User's Manual
nodes.description: A novel that describes the lives of the inhabitants of a Parisian apartment building at a single moment.

nodes.label: B. S. Johnson
nodes.description: An English experimental novelist who famously declared that 'truth is the most important criterion of the novel'.

nodes.label: The Unfortunates
nodes.description: A 'book in a box' with unbound chapters that are intended to be read in a random order.

nodes.label: William Gaddis
nodes.description: An American novelist whose complex works often satirize corporate America and the arts.

nodes.label: The Recognitions
nodes.description: A massive novel exploring themes of forgery, authenticity, and religion.

nodes.label: Don DeLillo
nodes.description: An American novelist whose work explores themes of consumerism, media, and paranoia.

nodes.label: White Noise
nodes.description: A novel about a professor of Hitler studies whose life is disrupted by an 'airborne toxic event'.

nodes.label: Vladimir Nabokov
nodes.description: A Russian-American novelist known for his complex plots, witty wordplay, and unreliable narrators.

nodes.label: Pale Fire
nodes.description: A novel presented as a 999-line poem with a lengthy, and increasingly personal, commentary by a mad scholar.

nodes.label: Samuel Beckett
nodes.description: An Irish avant-garde novelist, playwright, and theatre director.

nodes.label: The Trilogy (Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable)
nodes.description: A series of three novels that explore the diminishing consciousness of their narrators.

nodes.label: John Barth
nodes.description: An American writer known for his postmodernist and metafictional work.

nodes.label: Lost in the Funhouse
nodes.description: A collection of short stories that self-consciously explores the conventions of fiction.

nodes.label: Robert Coover
nodes.description: An American writer and a pioneer of metafiction.

nodes.label: The Universal Baseball Association, Inc., J. Henry Waugh, Prop.
nodes.description: A novel about a man who creates a fantasy baseball league that begins to take over his life.

nodes.label: Donald Barthelme
nodes.description: An American author known for his playful, surreal, and fragmentary short stories.

nodes.label: Snow White
nodes.description: A postmodern retelling of the classic fairy tale.

nodes.label: Gilbert Sorrentino
nodes.description: An American novelist and poet associated with postmodernism.

nodes.label: Mulligan Stew
nodes.description: A wildly experimental novel about a writer struggling to create a new kind of fiction.

nodes.label: Kathy Acker
nodes.description: An American experimental novelist, punk poet, and performance artist.

nodes.label: Blood and Guts in High School
nodes.description: A punk-feminist novel that uses collage, pastiche, and appropriation to explore themes of power and identity.

nodes.label: Raymond Queneau
nodes.description: A French novelist, poet, and co-founder of the Oulipo.

nodes.label: Exercises in Style
nodes.description: A book that retells a simple story in 99 different rhetorical styles.

nodes.label: Julio Cortázar
nodes.description: An Argentine novelist whose work influenced the Latin American Boom.

nodes.label: 62: A Model Kit
nodes.description: An experimental novel that expands on an idea from his earlier work, 'Hopscotch'.

nodes.label: Alain Robbe-Grillet
nodes.description: A French writer and filmmaker, a key figure in the Nouveau Roman (New Novel) movement.

nodes.label: Jealousy
nodes.description: A novel told from the perspective of a jealous husband, focusing on minute descriptions of objects and events.

nodes.label: Marguerite Duras
nodes.description: A French novelist, playwright, and filmmaker, also associated with the Nouveau Roman.

nodes.label: The Lover
nodes.description: An autobiographical novel about her teenage affair with an older Chinese man in French Indochina.

nodes.label: Christine Brooke-Rose
nodes.description: A British writer and literary critic, known for her highly experimental novels.

nodes.label: Thru
nodes.description: A novel that deconstructs the very process of writing and reading.

nodes.label: Flann O'Brien
nodes.description: The pen name of Brian O'Nolan, an Irish novelist and humorist.

nodes.label: At Swim-Two-Birds
nodes.description: A metafictional novel featuring a story within a story, where the characters of one story rebel against their author.

nodes.label: Gertrude Stein
nodes.description: An American novelist, poet, playwright, and art collector, a pioneer of modernist literature.

nodes.label: The Making of Americans
nodes.description: A long, experimental novel that attempts to tell the history of 'everyone who is or was or will be living'.

nodes.label: Djuna Barnes
nodes.description: An American artist, illustrator, journalist, and writer who was a part of the Parisian bohemian community in the 1920s and 1930s.

nodes.label: Nightwood
nodes.description: A modernist novel known for its dense, poetic prose and exploration of queer identity.

nodes.label: John Dos Passos
nodes.description: An American novelist, best known for his U.S.A. trilogy.

nodes.label: U.S.A. Trilogy
nodes.description: A series of three novels that uses experimental techniques to paint a portrait of American society in the early 20th century.

nodes.label: William S. Burroughs
nodes.description: An American writer and a primary figure of the Beat Generation, known for his cut-up technique.

nodes.label: Naked Lunch
nodes.description: A non-linear novel composed of vignettes that can be read in any order.

nodes.label: Jennifer Egan
nodes.description: An American novelist and short story writer.

nodes.label: A Visit from the Goon Squad
nodes.description: A novel with a chapter structured as a PowerPoint presentation, exploring the lives of characters in the music industry.

nodes.label: Ali Smith
nodes.description: A Scottish author, playwright, academic and journalist.

nodes.label: How to Be Both
nodes.description: A novel with two parts that can be read in either order, telling the stories of a Renaissance artist and a modern-day teenager.

nodes.label: Eimear McBride
nodes.description: An Irish novelist whose debut novel, 'A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing', won several awards.

nodes.label: A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing
nodes.description: A novel written in a fragmented, stream-of-consciousness style that captures the inner turmoil of its protagonist.

nodes.label: Max Porter
nodes.description: An English writer, author of 'Grief Is the Thing with Feathers'.

nodes.label: Grief Is the Thing with Feathers
nodes.description: A hybrid of novella, prose poem, and essay, about a father and his two sons dealing with the death of their mother.

nodes.label: Anne Carson
nodes.description: A Canadian poet, essayist, and translator.

nodes.label: Autobiography of Red
nodes.description: A 'novel in verse' that retells the myth of Geryon and Herakles in a modern setting.

nodes.label: Lydia Millet
nodes.description: An American novelist whose work often has a satirical and philosophical bent.

nodes.label: Mermaids in Paradise
nodes.description: A comedic novel about a couple on their honeymoon who discover a colony of mermaids.

nodes.label: George Saunders
nodes.description: An American writer of short stories, essays, novellas, children's books, and novels.

nodes.label: Lincoln in the Bardo
nodes.description: A novel set during the American Civil War, told in a collage of historical texts and ghost voices.

nodes.label: William H. Gass
nodes.description: An American novelist, short story writer, essayist, and critic.

nodes.label: The Tunnel
nodes.description: A long, experimental novel about a history professor who digs a tunnel out of his basement.

nodes.label: Metafiction
nodes.description: Fiction that self-consciously addresses the devices of fiction, exposing the 'truth' of a work of literature.

nodes.label: Non-linear Narrative
nodes.description: Where events are portrayed out of chronological order, or in other ways where the narrative does not follow a direct causality pattern.

nodes.label: Postmodernism
nodes.description: A literary movement characterized by skepticism, irony, and a rejection of grand narratives.

nodes.label: Stream of Consciousness
nodes.description: A narrative mode that depicts the multitudinous thoughts and feelings which pass through the mind.

nodes.label: Unreliable Narrator
nodes.description: A narrator whose credibility has been seriously compromised, forcing the reader to question the narrative.

nodes.label: Ergodic Literature
nodes.description: Literature that requires a 'non-trivial' effort from the reader to traverse the text.

nodes.label: Pastiche
nodes.description: The imitation of the style or character of other works of art.

nodes.label: Fragmentation
nodes.description: The breaking up of a narrative into disjointed pieces, reflecting a sense of a fractured reality.

nodes.label: Oulipo
nodes.description: A group of writers and mathematicians who use constrained writing techniques.

nodes.label: Encyclopedic Novel
nodes.description: A long, complex, fictional work that incorporates extensive information from a wide range of subjects.

nodes.label: Intertextuality
nodes.description: The shaping of a text's meaning by another text, through allusion, quotation, and other references.

nodes.label: Modernism
nodes.description: A philosophical and arts movement that arose from broad transformations in Western society during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

nodes.label: Nouveau Roman
nodes.description: A French literary movement of the 1950s that sought to create a new form of the novel, focusing on objects and surfaces.

nodes.label: Absurdism
nodes.description: The belief that human beings exist in a purposeless, chaotic universe, often expressed with dark humor.

edges.target: If on a winter's night a traveler
The Trilogy (Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable)
The Universal Baseball Association, Inc., J. Henry Waugh, Prop.
Blood and Guts in High School
A Visit from the Goon Squad
A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing
Grief Is the Thing with Feathers

edges.source: If on a winter's night a traveler
A Visit from the Goon Squad
A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing
The Trilogy (Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable)
Blood and Guts in High School
Grief Is the Thing with Feathers

commentary: Deconstruct the narrative with Experimental Fiction, where form is as important as content.
